X.T: Git‚Äôs database internals I: packed object store

X.T: Git‚Äôs database internals II: commit history queries
X.ST: This post explores Git commit history as a database where ‚Äògit log‚Äô is the query language. Learn about Git‚Äôs custom query index ‚Äì the commit-graph file ‚Äì and how to make sure it's enabled in your repositories.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the commit-graph and generation numbers, and how they are used. (DerrickStolee already explained this in some previous articles.)

X.T: Git‚Äôs database internals III: file history queries
X.ST: Git‚Äôs file history queries use specialized algorithms that are tailored to common developer behavior. Level up your history spelunking skills by learning how different history modes behave and which ones to use when you need them.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of some git log options: --show-pulls, --full-history, --full-history, and -L.

X.T: Git‚Äôs database internals IV: distributed synchronization

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The algorithms used by git fetch and git push, including the reachability bitmaps.

Background maintenance has been added with git maintenance, on-disk reverse indexes are now supported (disabled by default), and some small improvements.

X.ST: To celebrate this most recent release, here's GitHub's look at some of the most interesting features and changes introduced since last time.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The index now understands sparse checkouts, the bitmat format now supports multi-pack indexes, ort becomes the default merge strategy.

X.ST: The open source Git project just released Git 2.35. Here's GitHub's look at some of the most interesting features and changes introduced since last time.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: git stash --staged, new formats for git describe, SSH signing is improved, a new zdiff3 mode for reporting merge conflicts, some performance improvements in git diff‚Ä¶

X.ST: The open source Git project just released Git 2.37. Take a look at some of our highlights from the latest release.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Cruft packs have been added to better manage unreachable objects, a filesystem monitor is built in for Windows and macOS, the sparse index is now fully integrated‚Ä¶

X.ST: Another new release of Git is here! Take a look at some of our highlights on what's new in Git 2.38.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Scalar is now included in the release, git rebase can now update dependant branches, git rm supports spare index, git merge-tree supports the ort merge strategy‚Ä¶

X.ST: Another new release of Git is here to end the year! Take a look at some of our highlights on what's new in Git 2.39.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Improved grouping in git shortlog, git repack --expire-to can be used to generate a backup of the removed objects, git grep --cached improved performance with sparse index, and improved git push performance when some refs are hidden by the server.

X.ST: The first Git release of the year is here! Take a look at some of our highlights on what's new in Git 2.40.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: git jump now supports Emacs, git cat-file has been fixed to compute correct sizes when used with a mailmap, git check-attr can be used on a bare repository‚Ä¶

X.ST: The open-source Git project just released Git 2.41. Take a look at our highlights on what‚Äôs new in Git 2.41.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Cruft packs and reverse indexes are now generated by default, credential helpers support WWW-Authenticate headers, git fetch has a new --porcelain flag, git fsck performs more controls‚Ä¶

X.T: Git 2.41 release - Here are five of our contributions in detail

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The improvements and fixes that GitLab has contributed in Git 2.41.

X.ST: Another new release of Git is here! Take a look at some of our highlights on what's new in Git 2.42.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A new variant of the bitmap traversal algorithm, optimised scan of the packed-refs file, the gc.recentObjectsHook configuration allows to define hooks to avoid some files to be pruned‚Ä¶

X.T: Git 2.42 release: Here are four of our contributions in detail

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Adding -include and -exclude options to git pack-refs, adding a -Z option to git cat-file, allowing to provide pseudo options in stdin to git rev-list --stdin, and some code cleanup.

X.ST: The last Git release of 2023 is here! Take a look at some of our highlights on what's new in Git 2.43.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Multiple cruft packs, git repack now supports --filter and --filter-to to remove some blobs from the workspace, improved message for revert of revert, git log has now a %(decorate) placeholder‚Ä¶

X.T: The contributions we made to the Git 2.43 release

ARTICLE.COMMENT: git repack --filter, git show --exists, git rev-list --missing now handles missing commit objects, and reading attributes from HEAD by default.

X.ST: The first Git release of 2024 is here! Take a look at some of our highlights on what's new in Git 2.44.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Reusing objects across multiple packs, a new git replay which is a more powerful and faster alternative of git rebase, --autosquash for non-interactive rebase‚Ä¶

git replay, addition then removal of the detection of commits that exist in the commit-graph but no longer in the object database, preparation of a future new format to store refs, and integration of the definition of the GitLab CI/CD pipeline in Git repository.

X.ST: Git 2.45 is here with experimental support for reftables, and SHA-256 interoperability. Get our take on the latest here.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Reftable storage, first experiment of SHA-1/SHA-256 interoperability, git rev-list --missing=print now supports missing query tips, git reflog list can be use to how which references have a reflog even when using reftables, git config --comment can be used to comment a line, git cherry-pick now supports --empty‚Ä¶

git refs migrate can be used to convert a repo to reftables, git update-ref has new instructions to support symrefs, git config supports also the common command syntax, more unit tests, and some bug fixes.
